S6.T2.table:

44.43 867.80MB 260.12s 5.25%
k=1%∗d𝑘percent1𝑑k=1\%*d 65.31 648.54MB 285.19s 5.76%percent5.765.76\%

references:
To further explore the underling reason how BCFL improves the model accuracy, we compare the consumed training time of each algorithm to reach the target model accuracy by fixing the target model accuracy as 61%, 58% and 82% for three experiment scenarios, respectively.
We keep other settings the same as these in the experiment in Fig.
. The comparisons of training time are shown in Tables
(for FEMNIST), respectively. Here BFL represents the blockchain-based FL without model compression.
From results shown in these tables, we can draw the following conclusions.

The BCFL algorithm can always reach the target final model accuracy with the shortest training time. Despite that BCFL may not be the one with the least amount of communication traffic, it takes a smaller number of global iterations to complete model training such that the total training time cost is minimized. More importantly, BCFL can reduce the consumed training time by more than 90% compared with BFL.

Our results show the merit of our algorithm to optimally adjust the compression rate in BCFL. If the compression rate is too high, it can considerably slow down the convergence rate presented in Theorem

. Although the communication traffic can reduced significantly, it takes more global iterations to reach the target model accuracy, Inversely, if the compression rate is too low, it consumes excessive communication traffic to complete a round of global iteration, which inevitably consumes exorbitant training time.

A1.T5.caption: TABLE V: Notation Meaning in Time Cost Analysis
A1.T5.table:
Notation Meaning
Y𝑌Y total training time
τl​o​c​a​lsubscript𝜏𝑙𝑜𝑐𝑎𝑙\tau_{local} time required for clients to train the model locally
τ↑,isubscript𝜏↑𝑖\tau_{\uparrow,i} time required for client i𝑖i to upload the model updates to corresponding miner
τc​r​o​s​s,jsubscript𝜏𝑐𝑟𝑜𝑠𝑠𝑗\tau_{cross,j} time required for miner j𝑗j to receive the transactions crossed from other miners
τm​i​n​e,jsubscript𝜏𝑚𝑖𝑛𝑒𝑗\tau_{mine,j} time required for miner j𝑗j to complete the consensus mechanism
τp​r​osubscript𝜏𝑝𝑟𝑜\tau_{pro} time required for winning miner to propagate the block
τ↓,isubscript𝜏↓𝑖\tau_{\downarrow,i} time required for client i𝑖i to download the latest block from miner
τa​g​g​r​esubscript𝜏𝑎𝑔𝑔𝑟𝑒\tau_{aggre} time required for clients to aggregate the model updates in blocks
references: where k𝑘k is the parameter of the T​o​pk𝑇𝑜subscript𝑝𝑘Top_{k} compression algorithm. The explanation of each symbol for the time cost analysis is listed in Table V in Appendix.
To ease the interpretation of our analysis, we list brief explanations of major notations used in the time cost analysis and convergence analysis of Theorem 1 in Table V and Table VI, respectively.

Notation Meaning

references:
Please refer to Appendix B for the detailed proof.
The key to the proof is to construct an auxiliary sequence of centrally trained models. We then analyze the model’s updates in this sequence and its difference from the real trained model to derive the convergence.
To ease the interpretation of our proof, the explanation of notations used for the convergence proof is listed in Table VI in Appendix.
To ease the interpretation of our analysis, we list brief explanations of major notations used in the time cost analysis and convergence analysis of Theorem 1 in Table V and Table VI, respectively.
